questions.text: A patient presented with chronic sinusitis, ulcerative lesions on nasopharynx, nodular lesions with cavitation in the lungs and renal failure. What is the most important investigation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

ANCA for vasculitis The clinical features of the patient involving upper respiratory tract (sinusitis, ulcerative lesions on nasopharynx), lower respiratory tract (nodular lesions with cavitation in the lung) and Renal failure are suggestive of Wegener’s granulomatosis. To differentiate Wagener’s granulomatosis (c – ANCA positive) from Churg Strauss syndrome (p – ANCA positive), testing for c – ANCA is necessary.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Culture for fungus – There will be no history of renal failure and lung capitations in fungal infections Option D. AFB staining of sputum – Done for diagnosis of TB, but tuberculosis will not have renal failure

questions.text: Not a feature of Paroxysmal Nocturnal Haemoglobinuria?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Leukemia Paroxysmal nocturnal Haemoglobinuria is a acquired disorder due to mutation in PIGA gene (phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A gene) PNH cells are abnormally susceptible for lysis or injury by complement since they are deficient in three GPI linked proteins that regulate complement activity (CD55, CD59, C8 binding protein) Excess complement activation leads to : Pancytopenia + hypercellular bone marrow Intravascular Hemolysis – Hemoglobinuria Thrombosis Diagnosis Ham’s test – The abnormal sensitivity of RBCs, leukocytes and platelets to complement can be demonstrated in vitro using red cell lysis at acidic pH Flow cytometry – deficiency of CD55, CD59 Sucrose lysis test FLAER test – Fluorescein Labelled Proaerolysin test

questions.text: Cells/mediators involved in early part of Hypersensitivity type 1 reaction are? Mast cell Histamine Prostaglandins Neutrophils Leukotrienes Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a, b, c, e The mediators involved in early part of Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction are : Mast cells Histamine – Vasodilatation, Increased permeability of vessel wall, broncho constriction Prostaglandins (PG D2 – Bronchoconstriction, Vasodilatation, increased vascular permeability) Leukotrienes (Bronchoconstriction) Enzymes like neutral proteases (chymase, tryptase) and acid hydrolases Proteoglycans like heparin and chondroitin sulphate Lipid mediators – platelet activation factor Mediator involved in late phase of type 1 hypersensitivity reaction : Cytokines – TNF, IL-1, IL-4, IL-5 and Chemokines Leukocytes (eosinophils) Major basic protein (MBP) Eosinophil cationic protein

questions.text: Irradiation of RBCs prior to transfusion prevents which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Graft versus host disease Graft versus host reaction (GVHD) In GVHD, Immunologically active T cell of the donor destroys immunosuppressed tissues of the recipient. GVHD is of two types Acute GVHD – Occurs within days to weeks. May show rashes, jaundice, bloody diarrhoea. Chronic GVHD – may follow acute GVHD or may occur insidiously. These patients have extensive skin damage, with destruction of skin appendages and fibrosis of the dermis resembling systemic sclerosis, cholestatic jaundice, esophageal strictures, involution of thymus. Depletion of donor T cells by gamma irradiation, before transfusion can eliminate the occurrence of GVHD.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Immunomodulation – Decreasing the immune activity of the recipient HLA alloimmunization and TRALI – Prevented by avoiding donations from females with multiple previous pregnancies, multiple transfused donor.

questions.text: Arrange the following cellular events of inflammation in the right sequence? Rolling Adhesion Cytokine mediated integrin activation Migration Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A-C-B-D The correct sequence of cellular events that occur during inflammation are : Endothelial margination Rolling Cytokine mediated integrin activation Adhesion Leukocyte migration (Diapedesis) Chemotaxis Phagocytosis Killing

questions.text: Which of the following is a RNA based sequencing technique?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

RT-PCR RT-PCR (Reverse transcriptase Polymerase Chain Reaction) is a molecular analysis method used for the detection of RNA. mRNA is quantitated by generating the complementary DNA (cDNA) copies of the mRNA using reverse transcriptase enzyme.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Sanger’s technique DNA based sequencing (old technique) New technique – Next generation sequencing (NGS) Western blot Used in protein analysis Protein undergo electrophoresis 🡪 transferred to a membrane 🡪 tagged with specific antibodies 🡪 Visualised G Banding It is used in chromosome staining Visible karyotype is produced Useful in identifying the genetic diseases The metaphase chromosomes are treated with trypsin(to partially digest the chromosome) and stained with Giemsa stain

questions.text: Origin of CLL/SLL is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Naive B cells The cell of origin of CLL/SLL (Chronic lymphocytic leukemia and Small lymphocytic lymphoma) is Naive B cell. The CLL and SLL differ only in the degree of peripheral blood lymphocytes The most common genetic abnormalities seen are deletions of 13q14.3, 11q and 17p and trisomy 12q The growth of CLL/SLL is confined to the proliferation centers The tumor cells express CD19, CD20, CD23 and CD5 Richter’s transformation – CLL/SLL has a tendency to transform to a more aggressive DLBCL (Diffuse large B cell lymphoma)

questions.text: A 20 years old athlete suddenly collapsed while playing football and died. His case was diagnosed as a Sudden cardiac death. Based on the autopsy image shown below, what is the possible underlying cause?

options.label: A
options.text: Sudden cardiac death due to Arrythmia

options.label: B
options.text: Valvular heart disease due to RHD

options.label: C
options.text: Sudden cardiac death due to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

options.label: D
options.text: Sudden cardiac death due to Atherosclerosis

questions.correct_answer: A. Sudden cardiac death due to Arrythmia
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sudden cardiac death due to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy The sudden cardiac death in the athlete and the image showing asymmetrical septal hypertrophy is suggestive of sudden cardiac death due to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HOCM) is one of the most common cause of sudden, otherwise unexplained death in young athletes. Features: Diastolic dysfunction due to massive hypertrophy of left ventricle Dynamic obstruction of left ventricular outflow as the anterior mitral leaflet moves towards the ventricular septum during systole May lead to: Atrial fibrillation Stroke Intractable cardiac failure Ventricular arrhythmias Sudden death Mutations causing HOCM: β – myosin heavy chain (MHC/MYH7) Myosin binding protein C (MYBP – C) Histology: Massive myocyte hypertrophy Myofiber disarray Interstitial and replacement fibrosis Management: β blockers Implantable cardioverter – defibrillator

questions.text: In the activation of coagulation cascade following endothelial injury, identify the ‘A' which combines with Tissue Factor(TF) to activate factor IX?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Factor 7 Endothelial injury produces Tissue Factor which combines with Factor VII (7) and activated factor IX

questions.text: Best method to assess Hba 1c levels?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ion chromatography HbA1C is the glycated hemoglobin. It measures the mean glucose concentration over the past 6 to 8 weeks. Measurement of HbA1C is done by ion exchange chromatography. Ion exchange chromatography It is based on the charge – charge interactions Two types – Cation exchange chromatography and anion exchange chromatography Cation exchange – Proteins with net positive charge at a given pH will tightly adhere to the beads with negatively charged functional groups such as carboxylates and sulfates Anion exchange – Proteins with net negative charge at a given pH adhere to the beads with positively charged functional groups, typically tertiary or quaternary amines. Non adherent proteins are washed away

questions.text: Regarding tumor suppressor gene, which one is a correct statement? BRCA1 is an oncogene EGFR positive in seen in non-small cell cancer HER 2 neu amplification seen in fraction of breast cancer N-myc is a tumor suppressor gene Select the correct answer from the given below code:

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above are true

questions.explanation:
Solution:

b, c EGFR will be positive in non-small cell lung cancer. All the Breast cancers are separated into 3 major groups based on the expression of ER and HER Neu. HER 2 neu is expressed only in a fraction of people with breast cancer.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. BRCA1 is a tumor suppressor gene. It is a DNA repair gene. It is located on Chr. 17q21 Option D. N-myc is a proto-oncogene.

questions.text: Electron microscopic picture of an alveolus with capillary is given below. In a patient with ARDS due to SARS – COV2, which of the following layers will be expanded?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A In the given image of electron microscopy of blood air barrier of lungs, the marked structures are Type 2 pneumocytes Basement membrane Type 1 pneumocytes Endothelium In ARDS in patients with COVID – 19, neutrophils damage to the endothelial (labelled as D in the image) and alveolar epithelial cells, with inflammation is the key initiating event and the basis of lung damage. The side of location of the endothelial can be known by the side of location of the RBC. Type II pneumocyte hyperplasia is a common finding in ARDS due to the need for regeneration of the damaged type I pneumocytes

Highyeild:

Histopathological findings of ARDS Hyaline membranes : These are pink-staining, proteinaceous deposits that form on the inner surface of the alveoli, and are the hallmark of ARDS. Hyaline membranes are formed due to the accumulation of plasma proteins and cellular debris in the alveoli, resulting in damage to the alveolar-capillary barrier. Inflammation : ARDS is characterized by an inflammatory response in the lungs, which is indicated by the presence of neutrophils and macrophages in the alveoli and interstitial spaces. Edema : The alveolar-capillary barrier in the lungs becomes leaky in ARDS, leading to the accumulation of fluid in the alveoli and interstitial spaces, which is known as pulmonary edema. Alveolar damage : The histopathological features of ARDS include damage to the alveolar walls, leading to the collapse of the alveoli and impaired gas exchange in the lungs. Fibrosis : In some cases of ARDS, there may be the development of fibrosis (scarring) in the lungs, which can lead to long-term respiratory problems. https://images.app.goo.gl/BbY2go5WsikXVKyr7

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A,B & D: All are incorrect.

Table:

#MANTRA Phases of ARDS Phase Duration Features Exudative Day 1-7 Alveolar damage, hyaline membrane formation, interstitial edema, alveolar flooding, and surfactant depletion Proliferative Day 7-21 Inflammatory cells, fibroblasts, and myofibroblasts migrate to the alveoli, leading to fibrosis and collagen deposition Fibrotic Beyond day 21 Fibrosis, scarring, and remodeling of the lung tissue, leading to irreversible lung damage and impaired gas exchange

questions.text: A soft tissue mass excised from patient presenting with SNHL and tinnitus, biopsy taken shows the following. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Schwannoma The given image shows ‘verocay bodies’ suggestive of schwannoma.

Highyeild:

Schwannomas Schwannoma is a benign nerve sheath tumor that arises from Schwann cells. Classically present at the cerebellopontine angle Benign tumor involving CNs V, VII, and VIII but can also be along peripheral nerve Origin: Schwann cells, S-100 + Histology: Antoni A pattern : Spindle cells are arranged in intersecting fascicles with nuclear palisading and Verocay bodies. Antoni B pattern : Spindle cells separated by myxoid extracellular matrix, microcyst formation, and fewer cellular areas. The nucleus is wavy and buckled: This is a characteristic feature of schwannoma and is known as Verocay bodies. Bilateral schwannomas are found in NF-2

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Neurofibroma: These are tumors that arise from peripheral nerves and are composed of a mixture of different cell types, including Schwann cells, fibroblasts, and perineural cells. Additionally, neurofibromas are not commonly associated with SNHL and tinnitus. Option B. Rhabdomyoma: These are benign tumors that arise from skeletal muscle tissue. They are not typically associated with the eighth cranial nerve or the clinical symptoms of SNHL and tinnitus. Option D . Leiomyoma: These are benign tumors that arise from smooth muscle tissue. They are most commonly found in the uterus, gastrointestinal tract, and skin, but they are not commonly associated with the eighth cranial nerve or the symptoms of SNHL and tinnitus. Leiomyomas do not exhibit Verocay bodies, which are specific to schwannomas.

Extraedge:

Special features of schwannomas Roll over phenomenon Hitzelberger sign: Hypoesthesia of EAM posters-superiorly Most common presenting feature: Tinnitus Earliest ocular sign: loss of corneal reflex

Table:

#MANTRA Histological features of CNS tumors

questions.text: A 60 years old female presented with symptoms of confusion, thirst and abdominal pain. On examination, she had pallor and thoracic spine tenderness. X ray spine showed osteolytic lesions. Investigations revealed Hb 7gm%, Calcium 13mg/dl, TLC is 400/mm³ with normal DLC, Serum creatinine 2.3mg/dl, Total protein is 9g/dl and Albumin is 2.4g/dl. What is the underlying diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Multiple Myeloma The given clinical features: C - Hypercalcemia R – Renal failure (suggested by elevated creatinine) A – Anaemia B – Osteolytic bone lesions hypoalbuminemia with elevated total protein indicate multiple myeloma. Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of single clone of plasma cells. It is associated with an increased osteoclastic activity and suppressed osteoblastic activity causing punched out lesion in the bone and Hypercalcemia.

questions.text: The effect of G6PD deficiency is/are: Decrease in NADPH Decrease in reduced glutathione Decrease in lipid peroxidation Decreased RBC membrane damage Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a, b are correct G – 6 PD (Glucose – 6 – Phosphate Dehydrogenase) deficiency causes decrease in reduced glutathione and decreased NADPH and increased lipid peroxidation causing increased RBC membrane damage. G – 6 PD reduces NADP to NADPH while oxidizing glucose 6 phosphate. This NADPH provides the reducing equivalent for conversion of oxidized to reduced glutathione. Reduced glutathione acts as a cofactor in reactions that neutralize the compounds such as H2O2 So, in G-6-PD deficiency, when exposed to oxidative stress RBC membrane is damaged leading to Hemolysis.

questions.text: HPV produces a protein which suppresses RB gene. Which is it?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

E7 RB gene is a negative regulator of cell cycle at G1/S transition. It exist in two states: Hyperphosphorylated/inactive state Hypophosphorylated / active state E7 protein of Human papilloma virus (HPV) binds with hypophosphorylated(active) RB gene and displaces the E2F transcription factor, and promotes G1/S transition and progression of cell cycle.

questions.text: In reference to the histopathology given below, what is most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pemphigus vulgaris The given image shows suprabasal splitting of epidermis and row of tombstone appearance suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris. It occurs due to the antibodies mainly against desmoglein 3 and rarely against desmoglein 1. Features Flaccid bullae Both skin and mucosa involved Oral mucosa is commonly affected, other areas of ulceration can be seen in conjunctiva, nasopharynx and larynx etc. Cutaneous lesions are more common over scalp, face, neck, upper chest and back etc.

questions.text: The karyotype of an individual showed the following picture. Which of following clinical features may be seen in this patient ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gynaecomastia and long limbs The given karyotype have ‘47 XXY’ abnormality suggestive of klinefelter syndrome. In Klinefelter syndrome Gynaecomastia and long limbs are seen. Mnemonic - “K-L-I-N-E-F-E-L-T-S” K aryotype - 47XXY L ong stature and long legs I nfertility (Incidence : 1 in 1000 men) N on dysjunction of paternal sex chromosomes E unuchoid body proportions F SH levels elevated, Scanty Facial and axillary hair E stradiol/Testosterone ratio is elevated L H elevated, Leukemias (increased risk of AML) and breast tumors, Learning disabilities T estosterone reduced, small testis and penis S econdary sexual characters absent

questions.text: The given below is the histological image of pancreas. Which of the marked structure is affected in cystic fibrosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

C In the given image, the structures marked are: A – Pancreatic duct B – Blood vessels C – Exocrine pancreas D – Islets of Langerhans In cystic fibrosis , the Exocrine pancreas will be affected ( marked by ‘C' in the given image ). In cystic fibrosis, the CFTR protein defect leads to abnormal production of thick, sticky mucus. This mucus can block the ducts of the exocrine pancreas , preventing the normal flow of digestive enzymes into the small intestine. As a result, individuals with cystic fibrosis often experience pancreatic insufficiency.

Highyeild:

Normal histology of pancreas https://images.app.goo.gl/FRifGzRvQnMR1PYCA https://images.app.goo.gl/FRifGzRvQnMR1PYCA

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. D:Incorrect Option C .A:Incorrect Option D .B:Incorrect

Extraedge:

Features of cystic fibrosis Mucus accumulates in the pancreatic ducts Leads to dilatation of Exocrine pancreas. Mucus blocks the ducts completely atrophy and progressive fibrosis of the Exocrine pancreas Impairment of absorption of fat and fat soluble vitamins.

questions.text: The given Vacutainer contains which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Clot activator The given vacutainer have red stopper, hence it contains Clot activator (Silica)
